awd_titl_txt: Implementing Spaced Retrieval Practice Across Multiple STEM Domains to Enhance Student Learning in Barrier Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by improving learning in introductory STEM courses through spaced retrieval practice. Spaced retrieval practice requires students to periodically answer questions that require them to recall what they previously learned.  It is a is a memory-enhancing, research-based instructional technique that has been shown to improve memory of concepts both within and between semesters. Spaced retrieval practice is especially important in barrier courses where a lack of success restricts students from further pursuing STEM degrees.  This project will study the effectiveness of spaced retrieval practice in ten different introductory STEM courses. This intervention may be most beneficial to students who traditionally underperform in STEM, thus helping to broaden participation in STEM careers.

Building on previous results of the effectiveness of spaced retrieval in a few courses, this project aims to implementing and measuring the effects of spaced retrieval in ten different undergraduate STEM courses at the University of Louisville. Through a series of workshops, project team leaders will work with faculty to design spaced retrieval exercises for their courses. The intervention will then be implemented for one semester using the same implementation strategy in all courses, reaching a total of over 1,600 students. Retention of classroom content following spaced retrieval practice will be compared, in within-subjects fashion, to retention following massed retrieval practice. The effect of the practice manipulation (the magnitude of the difference between performance following spacing versus massing) will be compared across different courses, permitting assessment of spacing's effectiveness across domains. For those courses in which spaced retrieval practice is shown to be effective, the project will investigate whether the magnitude of the spacing-related benefit differs. In addition, it may be possible to detect other classroom design and demographic moderators of the effect, depending upon sample sizes and variations in classrooms. Results could provide evidence to support implementation of spaced retrieval as a strategy to increase student success in STEM courses nationwide. Increasing student success in STEM courses will lead to more individuals successfully pursuing STEM careers. It will also pave the way for future research to explore the impacts of spaced retrieval practice in the context of different types of institutions of higher education, potentially leading to even broader adoption of the intervention. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of Louisville Research Foundation Inc

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project implemented and assessed the effectiveness of spaced retrieval practice in ten introductory STEM courses, addressing two IUSE: EHR goals: 1) to use and build evidence about improved STEM instructional practice, and 2) to develop, implement, and test creative approaches for adoption of educational research into disciplinary teaching. Spaced retrieval practice is an evidence-based educational method in which learners are asked to retrieve the same information multiple times with temporal delays in between. The memory benefits of spacing have been shown extensively in laboratory experiments but relatively few studies have been performed in a classroom setting at this time.

In Year 1, the research team conducted a series of workshops for seven instructors of 10 different introductory courses in biology, chemistry, engineering, mathematics, physics, and psychology. Through these workshops as well as one-on-one trainings with the research team, the STEM faculty members acquired knowledge about spaced retrieval practice, learned how to implement it in their courses, and developed learning objectives and question sets for the project. In Year 2, all faculty implemented spaced retrieval practice in their courses in the same way by adding five biweekly quizzes to their existing course assignments. The research design embedded in these quizzes was within-subjects, with each student experiencing both massed and spaced retrieval practice conditions on half of the course-specific learning objectives. In the massed condition, three questions about the same topic were given on the same quiz. In the spaced condition, the three questions were spaced out over three consecutive quizzes. Learning was assessed on an end-of-semester criterial test, and student performance was compared between learning objectives that had been spaced and massed. In Year 3, the research team examined the impact of spacing in all courses but one, which did not have enough data for analysis due to low enrollment and participation.

Results were mixed. There was a significant learning benefit of spacing in two courses (Calculus I for engineering students, and Chemistry for Health Professionals) as well as positive, small-sized effects (Hedges’ gav > .20) in two additional courses (General Chemistry and Diversity of Life). The effects in the other five courses were not significant. A single-paper meta-analysis, similar to a traditional meta-analysis but pulling many results from within one large study, revealed a significant but very small effect of spacing. In addition, the heterogeneity was high, and the significance was dependent on the results from the calculus course. The generalizability of the spacing effect across STEM courses therefore remains unclear.

Performance on practice quizzes was also assessed. Results showed that spacing reduced performance on the practice quizzes in the calculus course, indicating some form of desirable difficulty during learning. The reduction in practice performance was nuanced: performance was lower in the spaced condition than the massed condition only on the first two quiz questions, and performance on the third question was the same in the massed and spaced conditions. These findings indicate that spacing led to more protracted, but ultimately more robust, learning. There were no other patterns of desirable difficulty in the other courses, also leading to an overall message of mixed results.

Although we could not clearly determine the generalizability of the benefits of spaced retrieval, our findings indicate that it could be a low-cost method of improving performance in at least some STEM courses. More work is needed to determine when, how and for whom spaced retrieval practice is most beneficial.  The effect of spacing in classroom settings may depend on some design features such as the nature of the retrieval practice activities (multiple choice versus short answer and/or feedback settings), as well as student actions (e.g., whether they look at feedback or study outside of retrieval practice opportunities).  In the discipline of cognitive science, our results push research in a more pragmatic direction.  In the discipline of STEM education, our results exposed the fact that spaced retrieval practice does not always result in learning gains. The evidence is promising, and further pragmatic research is encouraged.


Last Modified: 01/03/2024
Modified by: Patricia Ralston
